question_text:
Find the complex number $z$ such that
\[|z - 1| = |z + 3| = |z - i|.\]
response:
Let $z=a+bi.$ Then, using the given conditions and properties of absolute values,
\begin{align*}
|(a-1)+bi|&=|(a+3)+bi|=|(a+0i)-i|\\
\Rightarrow \qquad \sqrt{(a-1)^2+b^2}&=\sqrt{(a+3)^2+b^2}=\sqrt{a^2+(b-1)^2}
\end{align*}The last equality follows from the fact that $|z - i| = |z - 0i + i|$ implies $|(a) + (b)i - i|=|(a)+((b-1))i|.$ Therefore, we have
$$\sqrt{(a-1)^2+b^2}=\sqrt{(a+3)^2+b^2},$$
so squaring both sides and canceling the common factor of $b^2$ gives us \begin{align*}
(a-1)^2=(a+3)^2 &= a^2 + 6a +9\\
\Rightarrow \qquad (a-1)^2-(a^2 + 6a +9) =0\\
\Rightarrow \qquad -12a-8&=0\\
\Rightarrow \qquad a&=-\frac{4}{3}.
\end{align*} Substituting this value of $a$ into the equality $\sqrt{(a+3)^2+b^2}=\sqrt{a^2+(b-1)^2}$ then yields
$$\left(\frac{-4}{3}-3\right)^2 + b^2 = \left(-\frac{4}{3}\right)^2 +(b-1)^2,$$which gives us
\begin{align*}
25/9+b^2&=\frac{16}{9}+b^2 -2b+1\\
&= \frac{25}{9}-2b + 1
\end{align*} Subtracting $\frac{25}{9}$ from both sides, we obtain $b-2b=-\frac{14}{9},$ or equivalently $b=\frac{7}{3}.$ Therefore, our desired complex number is $\boxed{-\frac{4}{3}+\frac{7}{3}i}.$
